content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @lyse why do you avoid to bring people here?

@lyse@lyse.isobeef.org Your comments around maintaining your ‚Äúfilter bubble‚Äù and ‚Äúbeing able to keep up‚Äù are things I think we should try to find good ways and tools to manage. I too like the filter bubble I‚Äôve created around myself (so far) and probably want to mostly keep it that way (more or less). Yes keeping up is getting harder, which has driven me to work on and experiment with ‚ÄúFiltering‚Äù.

I don‚Äôt really see Twtxt / Yarn.social as a ‚Äúsocial media‚Äù per se, I see it more of an ecosystem and an easy way to get a ‚Äúthought‚Äù or two out there with some familiar things (of course) borrowed from ‚Äúsocial media‚Äù. Remember that I think much of the same concepts really predated the likes of Twitter/Facebook anyway (finger? Status.net? and others‚Ä¶) so the ‚Äúsour taste‚Äù we have is maybe ill placed?

Anyway, let‚Äôs keep trying to make something good ü§ó

Bleh, I hate the Javascript/NodeJS/npm ecosystem so much ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Just trying to modify a simple CICD Github Actions workflow and since its written in Javascript and uses god knows what the hell dependencies, it wants to pull in half the fucking NPM world ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
content.value: Bleh, I hate the Javascript/NodeJS/npm ecosystem so much ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Just trying to modify a simple CICD Github Actions workflow and since its written in Javascript and uses god knows what the hell dependencies, it wants to pull in half the fucking NPM world ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

@darch@neotxt.dk This is also an option üëå Personally I tend to prefer the ‚ÄúShare via ‚Ä¶‚Äù bookmarklet, because you‚Äôre sort of saying ‚ÄúHey y‚Äôall, check this thing out I want to share with you‚Äù üòÖ I feel like an RSS -> Twtxt feed of a blog is kind of different somehow? ü§î

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Are you guys aware of the notes section of my website? Should I announce new notes here like I do with blog posts?

FWIW I think you should. Use the Share via twtxt.net bookmarklet feature (which you‚Äôll find in Settings -> Tools).

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª I think sadly we saw a bunch of spam/bot accounts created on various pods throughout the network üò¢ besides up and coming "invite system" we plan to build, not sure there is much more we can do ü§£ Oh well ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci Yeah me too! üôè

So I discovered (get it? ü§£) that there is a Twtxt feed out there that is otherwise identical but are served as two different feeds with a different # url = field for some strange reason, even though the content is literally identical üòÖ

You can see what I mean by poking around these two twts: #jbsw56q and #bekvqja

Basically if you‚Äôre going to serve your feed over different protocols or a different URL on the same protocol/scheme, you really should use the same # url = (Hashing URI as per the spec) ü§ó
content.value:
So I discovered (get it? ü§£) that there is a Twtxt feed out there that is otherwise identical but are served as two different feeds with a different # url = field for some strange reason, even though the content is literally identical üòÖ
You can see what I mean by poking around these two twts: #jbsw56q and #bekvqja
Basically if you‚Äôre going to serve your feed over different protocols or a different URL on the same protocol/scheme, you really should use the same # url = (Hashing URI as per the spec) ü§ó

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @darch @abucci @movq Hmm, comparision to e-mail lacks quite a few important bits I reckon. First of all, the pull mechanism applies only to the receiving e-mail part. However, sending mails is push, maybe some yarnd gossipping fills in that gap, no idea. Also there's no e-mail address equivalent, so everybody can read your stuff (ok, true for unencrypted e-mails, too), but here literally everybody can read your feed. Also, the complexity of e-mail is a very different beast.

@lyse@lyse.isobeef.org Actually you are somewhat right about and I empathise with your point of view. As much as I believe in what we‚Äôve built here, I also recognise its not for everyone. The ‚Äúmasses‚Äù (as we call ‚Äòem) are (as you say) truly lost. It is next to impossible to pry them away from all this centralised privacy eroding garbage as they almost just ‚Äúdon‚Äôt get it‚Äù.

I‚Äôve found myself saying in conversations with my wife and friends and family, with the increase in data branches, that we will only start to question the way things are and where our data is stored and with whom, only (and only if) it started to hurt a lot more than it already is.

With the recent branches of Optus and Medibank here in Australia, Australians are starting to feel the pain of identity fraud, theft, increased difficulty in dealing with institutions (like taking your own money out of a bank!) and so on‚Ä¶

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @abucci You were making a joke, but I‚Äôd wager that many people actually respond like that. üòÇ ‚ÄúWhat, it‚Äôs like email? Full of spam?!‚Äù

@eaplmx Haha ü§£ But it‚Äôs so true right üòÖ it‚Äôs nothing to do with ‚Äútech‚Äù, it is everywhere. As we build more and more complicated ‚Äúthings‚Äù we lose our understanding of how anything actually works üòÖ ‚Äì We (as a human race) would be so royally screwed if the Sun was to hit us with a south facing solar flare, or an asteroid were to strike the earth again ü§£
